answers.answer: You don't mention your age or general health but that could be a sign of occlusive vascular disease of the main arteries of the neck or head. Especially true if you smoke, have high blood pressure, diabetes, a family histroy of cardiovascular disease or are > 65 years old. Have it check out by an ophthalmologist (Eye MD) first. He/She may refer you to a cardiologist, neurologists or Internist.JCH III MD  Eye MD = Ophthalmologist

Hello Mathew82 I don't think your theory is possible. The eye muscles have something like a 100 times the strength needed to move the eyes. So unlike chest and arms muscles that are excersized hard, the eye muscles do not get "bulked up" no matter how much you use them. The ring you see in you eye when you push the eye with your finger-tip is an entoptic phenomena and is caused by the fact that the retina reponds not only to light but to traction and pressure. That also is the reason "arching" is seen with rapid eye movements in a dark adapted eye.I do approve of your plans to see an ophthalmologist for a specific diagnosis and comprehensive exam.JCH III MD Eye MD
